p.s: Many stage directions like pauses or dramatic dialogue are used to create a certain tension between the characters Karl and Russ.
Right from the beginning there is a certain tension when Russ interrupts Karl from his argumentation all the time.
Need you to stop now(l. 8) or No.No more. (l. 23) are a quick exchange of statements, so the pace and tense of the atmosphere are increasing.
When both stop talking for a short period of time, as we can see because of the stage direction (cf. l. 39), there is a moment of silence intended to prepare for a climax.
The same moment of hesistation can be found in l. 14-15, when the church bell begins to ring.
Both are trying to be dominant, they tend to assume a superior role by starting their sentences several times with Well, ... (ll. 42, 44, 51).
It is called a lengthy contribution.
The fact that Karl and Russ are constantly overlapping and interrupting each other, leads to unfinished sentences, which increases the tension between them massively (cf. ll. 84ff.).

Besides all the interruptions, Russ starts to use colloquial language like what son of a bitch or I give a rat's ass (ll. 95-96, 98-99), which shows how much his annoyance and anger grows, because he asked Karl already many times to leave the house.
Karl gets more defensive and indifferent when Russ complains about all the things how the community affects his and his wifewife's lives (cf. ll. 101ff.).
Karl seems to be rather quiet during Russ's argumentation, almost inferior.
He gets uncomfortable in this role and wants more attention, so he shifts the focus on him and his wife, who is two weeks from giving birth (ll. 107f.).
In the end, Russ is so annoyed about Karl and disgusted by the whole community Karl represents that he removes the letter on yellow legal paper (ll. 155-156) and starts to read a little (l. 158).
Russ seems to be a bit calmer and dedicated to make Karl and the whole community feel bad about the loss of his son and the way they are treating non Clybourne Park members, as well as his family.
Now there is Bev who wants to stop Russ from reading the last letter from their son out loud and starts interrupting him (cf. l. 160).
She means to imply strong emotions by almost screaming Stop it (ll. 162, 165f.) all the time.
These words (Italics) are quite emphasized.
The extract ends when Russ is holding an reproach to Karl to reveal the truth.
They all end up by standing in silence, Bev is crying and Russ slowly folds the letter (ll. 203ff.).
This pause represents the speechlessness, shock and embarrassment everybody except Russ seems to feel.
He seems to feel satisfied and content.
His intention was all the time that it does not matter who is gonna move in, what only matters for him and his wife is to move out and leave the part behind.
There was a vast climax in the extract of Act I, which was created by many italics and pauses.
They lead to the final point where Russ turned into the dominant and superior part and stated his view without any interruptions from anybody.
